title: 115_hr1777
content:
Improvement and enhancement of authorities regarding military technicians (dual status). The text of section 709 of title 32, United States Code is amended to allow for the employment of technicians for various purposes in support of the National Guard and armed forces under regulations prescribed by the Secretary of Defense. The amended section 709 of title 32, United States Code allows technicians to support operations or missions requested by the President or Secretary of Defense, Federal training operations, and instruct or train active-duty members, foreign military forces, and Department of Defense contractors in the US or its territories. In section 709 of title 32, United States Code, technicians employed by the Department of Defense can include Department of Defense contractor personnel and Department of Defense civilian employees. A technician is defined as a person employed by the Department of the Army or the Department of the Air Force, who is a member of the National Guard, outside the competitive service, and holds a specified military grade. The adjutants general appoint, employ, and administer technicians authorized by this section. Technicians must adhere to military regulations and wear appropriate uniforms. Non-dual status technicians are designated in accordance with regulations prescribed by the Secretary of Defense. A person employed as a military technician (dual status) must adhere to regulations set by the Secretary of Defense. If separated from the National Guard or fails to meet military standards, they will be promptly separated from their technician employment. A military technician (dual status) can be separated from employment by the adjutant general for cause or through adverse actions like reduction in force. The Secretary of Defense or Chief of the National Guard Bureau cannot order furloughs for military technicians. In cases of reduction in force or adverse actions, the adjutant general has the authority to take action for non-dual status technician employment. Appeals for military technicians (dual status) must be through military proceedings and cannot extend beyond the adjutant general for issues during military pay status. The adjutant general has authority for non-dual status technician employment issues. Appeals for military technicians (dual status) must go through military proceedings and cannot extend beyond the adjutant general for matters during military pay status. Military technicians have a right of appeal to an administrative panel for certain activities related to technician duties, with the panel's decision being final and binding. In the case of a military technician (dual status), appeals concerning discrimination in non-military aspects of employment must go through military proceedings and cannot extend beyond the adjutant general. The termination of employment for a military technician must be notified in writing at least 30 days in advance, except in specific circumstances. Military technicians separated involuntarily, except for misconduct, are granted priority 1 consideration. Military technicians separated involuntarily, except for misconduct, are granted priority 1 consideration under the Department of Defense priority placement program and full eligibility under the Interagency Career Transition Assistance Plan. Certain sections of title 5 do not apply to individuals employed under this section, and the Secretary concerned may prescribe exceptions to specific provisions of law. The Secretary concerned may prescribe the hours of duty for technicians. Non-dual status technicians are granted compensatory time off for irregular or overtime work. Military technicians (dual status) may be paid one and a half times their basic pay rate for irregular or overtime work, or granted compensatory time off. The Secretary may not set qualifications for non-dual status technicians that are different from those for other National Guard members. The adjutant general can set qualifications for dual status military technicians. Military duty standards refer to requirements for military service, while military pay status is defined as a period of duty. The term 'military pay status' refers to a period of service where a technician's pay is based on military pay rates. Payment for overtime work for military technicians is contingent upon regulations prescribed by the Secretary of Defense. Enhancement of benefits for military technicians (dual status) is addressed in Section 2. Section 10216 of title 10, United States Code, is amended to allow military technicians (dual status) who are already members of a reserve component to keep enlistment, reenlistment, or affiliation bonuses when they become employed. This includes the opportunity to participate in educational benefits. The amendment allows military technicians (dual status) in a reserve component to retain bonuses and participate in educational loan repayment programs. Additionally, it grants TRICARE Standard eligibility to members enrolled in a health benefits plan under chapter 89 of title 5. SEC. 3. Fiscal Year 2018 end strengths for National Guard military technicians (dual status) are specified for the Army National Guard and Air National Guard. The Army National Guard end strength is set at 25,507, and the Air National Guard end strength is set at 22,103.

SEC. 4. Requirements regarding the conversion of military technician (dual status) positions are modified. Section 1053(a) of the National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2016 is amended to convert military technician positions to non-military technician positions in general administration, clerical, finance, and office service starting October 1, 2017. The Secretary of Defense can convert certain occupations to non-military technician positions, limited to 4.8% of National Guard and Reserve military technician positions as of October 1, 2017. SEC. 5 amends Section 328(b) of title 32, United States Code, to include additional duties in support of State missions for National Guard members called to active duty by Governors. SEC. 6 modifies personnel management authorities for the Chief of the National Guard Bureau. Section 10508(b) of title 10, United States Code, is amended to allow for the appointment, employment, administration, detailing, and assignment of persons under specific sections within the National Guard Bureau and various states for execution of certain programs. The amendment allows Columbia, Guam, and the Virgin Islands to carry out National Guard functions and missions assigned by the Chief of the National Guard Bureau. The adjutants general have the authority to appoint, employ, and administer personnel within their jurisdictions.
